column1: Brachial plexus injury is a loss of movement or weakness of the arm.
The nerves of the brachial plexus can be injured during a difficult delivery.

The injury may be caused by: - The infant's head and neck pulling toward the side as the shoulders pass through the birth canal - Pulling on the infant's shoulders during a head-first delivery - Pressure on the baby's raised arms during a breech (feet-first) delivery There are different forms of brachial plexus injury in an infant.
Although a C-section reduces the risk of injury it does not prevent it, and the procedure carries other risks.
This is when the infant has a fracture and is not moving the arm because of pain, but there is no nerve damage.

They may include: - No movement in the newborn's upper or lower arm or hand - Absent Moro reflex on the affected side - Arm flexed (bent) at elbow and held against body - Decreased grip on the affected side
In these cases there may be a separation of the nerve root from the spinal cord (avulsion).
- Permanent, partial, or total loss of function of the affected nerves, causing paralysis of the arm or arm weakness
